title: First inauguration of Calvin Coolidge
added: The '''first inauguration of Calvin Coolidge''' as the [[List of Presidents of the United States|30th]] [[President of the United States]] was held on Friday, August 3, 1923, at the [[Coolidge Homestead]] in [[Plymouth Notch, Vermont|Plymouth Notch]], [[Vermont]], following the death of President [[Warren G. Harding]] the previous evening. The [[United States presidential inauguration|inauguration]] – the sixth non-scheduled, extraordinary inauguration to ever take place – marked the commencement of the first term (a partial term of {{age in years and days|1923|8|3|1925|3|4}}) of [[Calvin Coolidge]] as President. The [[Oath of office of the President of the United States|presidential oath of office]] was administered to the new president by his father, [[John Calvin Coolidge Sr.]], who was a Vermont [[notary public]] and [[justice of the peace]].<ref>Calvin Coolidge, Bartleby.com: http://www.bartleby.com/124/pres47.html</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inaugural.senate.gov/about/past-inaugural-ceremonies/swearing-in-of-vice-president-calvin-coolidge-after-the-death-of-president-warren-g-harding/|title=The swearing in of Calvin Coolidge, August 3, 1923|publisher=United States Senate|access-date=April 9, 2020}}</ref> On Tuesday, August 21, 1923, President Coolidge repeated the oath before Justice [[Adolph A. Hoehling Jr.]] of the [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|Court of the District of Columbia]] at the [[Willard InterContinental Washington|Willard Hotel]], [[Washington, D.C.]]

[[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] Coolidge was visiting his family homestead in Vermont, which did not have [[electricity]] or a [[telephone]], when he received word by messenger of Harding's death.<ref name=fuess308>[[Claude Fuess|Fuess, Claude Moore]], "Calvin Coolidge: The Man from Vermont," Little, Brown, 1940, 308–309</ref> As the new president, Coolidge intended to take the oath of office and greet reporters who had assembled outside. He dressed in an upstairs bedroom, said a [[prayer]], and came downstairs.<ref name=fuess308/>

In front of a small group of observers, including Coolidge's wife [[Grace Coolidge|Grace]] and [[United States Representative]] [[Porter H. Dale]], his father, [[John Calvin Coolidge Sr.]], a Vermont [[notary public]] and [[justice of the peace]],<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.let.rug.nl/usa/presidents/calvin-coolidge/inaugural-address-1925.php |title = Inaugural address 1925 < Calvin Coolidge < Presidents < American History from Revolution to Reconstruction and beyond}}</ref> administered the [[Oath of office#United States|oath of office]]. The swearing in took place in John Coolidge's family parlor by the light of a [[kerosene]] lamp at 2:47 a.m. on August 3, 1923; President Coolidge then went back to bed.

Dale was campaigning for the [[United States Senate]] when he heard of Harding's death. He traveled to John Coolidge's home with reporter Joe Fountain, Herbert P. Thompson, the commander of [[Springfield, Vermont|Springfield]]'s [[American Legion]] Post, and labor union official L. L. Lane.<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.americanheritage.com/content/lamplight-inauguration?page=2 | title=Lamplight Inauguration | AMERICAN HERITAGE}}</ref> Dale had intended to ensure that Calvin Coolidge was informed that Harding had died, and to offer any assistance he could provide. As a result, Fountain was the only reporter present for the oath-taking.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/obituaries/joseph-fountain-82-witness-to-coolidge-s-oath-of-office.html |title = Joseph Fountain, 82, Witness to Coolidge's Oath of Office|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 1981-11-04}}</ref> By most accounts, it was Dale who suggested persistently that Coolidge be sworn in immediately to ensure continuity in the presidency. Dale later wrote an account of this event which was published as a magazine article.<ref>Bill Harris, [https://books.google.com/books?id=q8daE8a_KAoC&pg=PA456 The First Ladies Fact Book], 2012, page 456</ref><ref>Glenn D. Kittler, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=Rdf2UaOmJ9Ol4APT44CICg&id=XZ4MAQAAMAAJ&dq=porter+dale+swearing+in+calvin+coolidge&q=porter+dale Hail to the Chief!: The Inauguration Days of our Presidents], 1965, page 167</ref><ref>Porter H. Dale, The Calvin Coolidge Inauguration Revisited: An Eyewitness Account by Congressman Porter H. Dale, republished in Vermont History magazine, 1994, Volume 62, pages 214–222</ref> The ceremony was recreated for photographers the following morning.<ref>https://www.newsweek.com/every-us-presidential-inauguration-mckinley-photos-540643?slide=5</ref> The site is now a state park.

[[Albert W. Harvey]], the [[United States Marshal]] for the [[United States District Court for the District of Vermont|District of Vermont]], arrived in Plymouth about three hours after Coolidge was sworn in.<ref name="Brown">{{cite book |editor1-last=Brown |editor1-first=Henry Collins |editor1-link=Henry Collins Brown |date=1924 |title=Valentine's Manual of Old New York |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=igYcAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA366 |location=New York, NY |publisher=Chauncey Holt Co. |pages=366–370 |via=[[Google Books]]}}</ref> Swiftly deputizing several local residents, he took the initiative to provide a bodyguard detail for Coolidge.<ref name="Brown"/> The guards remained with Coolidge until [[United States Secret Service|Secret Service]] agents from [[Boston]] took over the duty after they caught up to his train in [[Rutland (city), Vermont|Rutland]] while he was returning to [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name="Brown"/>

Coolidge returned to Washington the next day, and Justice [[Adolph A. Hoehling Jr.]] of the [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|Court of the District of Columbia]] administered the oath a second time, on August 21, 1923, as there was a question about whether a state official had the authority to administer the federal presidential oath.<ref>Fuess, 310–315</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=David |last=Greenberg |title=Calvin Coolidge: The 30th President, 1923–1929 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wq1D6hcYlFwC |publisher=Macmillan |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-8050-6957-0 |pages=43–44}}</ref> The [[United States Constitution]] requires the President to take an oath at the beginning of his term, but it does not identify the person or officer who is to administer the oath.<ref>U.S. Const. art. II, s. 1</ref> It is traditional for the [[Chief Justice of the United States]] to administer the oath, but that is not a constitutional requirement. When [[George Washington]] was [[First inauguration of George Washington|sworn in on April 30, 1789]], neither the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] nor any other part of the federal judiciary had been created. The oath was administered by [[Robert Livingston (chancellor)|Robert Livingston]], a [[New York State|New York]] state judicial officer.

Hoehling kept the second swearing-in a secret until confirming [[Harry M. Daugherty]]'s revelation of it in 1932.<ref name="Second Oath">{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |date=February 2, 1932 |title=Confirms Daugherty's Story of Coolidge's Second Oath |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/138860690/ |work=St. Louis Post-Dispatch |location=St. Louis, MO |page=1C |url-access=subscription }}</ref> When Hoehling confirmed Daugherty's story, he indicated that Daugherty, then serving as [[United States Attorney General]], asked him to administer the oath at the [[Willard InterContinental Washington|Willard Hotel]].<ref name="Second Oath" /> According to Hoehling, he did not question Daugherty's reason for requesting a second oath-taking, but assumed it was to resolve any doubt about whether the first swearing-in was valid, since it had been administered by a state official.<ref name="Second Oath" />
